> Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1
> 
> I think we should remove all parameters with non-default values, not add them. Having these here means that if oslo.rootwrap changes the default value, we will never get it.

The current description is based on the example file provided by oslo.rootwrap.
 https://github.com/openstack/oslo.rootwrap/blob/master/etc/rootwrap.conf.sample

Having these defaults have a different benefit that any change in defaults doesn't cause direct breakage and I tend to keep the current strategy to hard-code defaults.
I don't think those parameters are actually needed as they have a default value, so unless we modify them for some reason, we don't need to explicit them in our custom rootwrap.conf

build-tools/stx/debrepack.py.message: Do you want to log something here since you are returning False or is that a common scenario.

As a minor nit,  there are two places this method which return False.
You have a debug log in one place but not the other.

Also ran into another problem building platform-utils, sysinv-agent, and sysinv-fpga-agent when a file/directory in the src_files list has the same name as the debname. For example:

 ---
 debname: platform-util
 debver: 1.0-1
 src_path: null
 src_files:
   - platform-util
   - scripts
 revision:
   dist: $STX_DIST
   PKG_GITREVCOUNT: true


resulted in:

 debrepack - INFO - === Package Path: /localdisk/designer/rchurch/starlingx-2/cgcs-root/stx/utilities/utilities/platform-util
 debrepack - INFO - [ Run - "cp -r /import/mirrors/starlingx/sources/platform-util /localdisk/loadbuild/rchurch/starlingx-2/std" ]
 debrepack - INFO - [ Run - "cp -rL platform-util /localdisk/loadbuild/rchurch/starlingx-2/std/platform-util/platform-util-1.0" ]
 debrepack - INFO - [ Run - "cp -rL /localdisk/designer/rchurch/starlingx-2/cgcs-root/stx/utilities/utilities/platform-util/scripts /localdisk/loadbuild/rchurch/starlingx-2/std/platform-util/platform-util-1.0" ]
 debrepack - INFO - [ Run - "cd /localdisk/loadbuild/rchurch/starlingx-2/std/platform-util; tar czvf platform-util_1.0.orig.tar.gz platform-util-1.0" ]

Here's my fix. I'm not sure if this covers all the cases per the design, but allows these packages to build.

 modified   build-tools/stx/debrepack.py
 @@ -251,8 +251,9 @@ class Parser():
              src_files = self.meta_data['src_files']
              self.meta_data['src_files'] = []
              for src_file in src_files:
 -                src_path = os.path.expandvars(src_file)
 -                if not os.path.exists(src_path):
 +                if os.path.expandvars(src_file) != src_file:
 +                    src_path = os.path.expandvars(src_file)
 +                else:
                      src_path = os.path.join(self.pkginfo["pkgpath"], src_file)
                  if not os.path.exists(src_path):
                      self.logger.error("No such file %s", src_path)

Yes, the root cause is debrepack finds the "src_files" where build-pkgs runs. Dan and Davlet also pointed it out. I send a new review https://review.opendev.org/c/starlingx/root/+/823745 to fix it by replacing the os.path.exists with os.path.isabs.

I tried out this commit along with the new download script. In order to get things building for me, I needed to add the following after setting up the local mirrors:

 modified   build-tools/stx/build-pkgs
 @@ -563,7 +563,7 @@ class BuildController():
                  os.makedirs(pkgdir)
  
          try:
 -            dsc_recipes = self.kits['dsc_maker'].package(pkg_meta)
 +            dsc_recipes = self.kits['dsc_maker'].package(pkg_meta,  os.path.join(os.environ.get('STX_MIRROR'), 'sources')) 
          except Exception as e:
              logger.error(str(e))
              return None

Thanks and I submit your fix to this commit:
https://review.opendev.org/c/starlingx/root/+/823724

nice one but is there a scenario where we would like to add a different role or rule to both os_compute_api:servers:show:host_status and os_compute_api:servers:show:host_status:unknown-only? This is a bit limiting in this area but I think it's a good change for now.

deployment/nova/nova-api-container-puppe.message:
I have to point out something unfortunately a bit complicated about showing host_status to non-admin.

The host_status controlled by os_compute_api:servers:show:host_status is a full host status that will show detail like: UP, DOWN, MAINTENANCE, UNKNOWN. DOWN means forced_down, MAINTENANCE means disabled, UNKNOWN means a heartbeat was not received within the configured threshold.

Because some operators do not wish to expose this much detail, another policy was added: os_compute_api:servers:show:host_status:unknown-only [1] that is a limited host status that will only show: UNKNOWN if the host is in status UNKNOWN and it will not reveal UP, DOWN, or MAINTENANCE.

I think we should provide both options os_compute_api:servers:show:host_status and os_compute_api:servers:show:host_status:unknown-only for operators so that they can get exactly the behavior they want, depending on how much information about cloud internals they are willing to expose.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/679181
[2] https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/configuration/policy.html

so we could follow that path of adding knobs for a case-specific policies, or perhaps modify both NovaRestrictLiveMigration/NovaShowHostStatus and NovaRestrictLiveMigrationRole/NovaApiHostStatusPolicy to cover a generic interface for overriding arbitrary policies in NovaApiPolicies

yes, given that that environment file references NovaApiPolicy, if there is need in more customizations, the only viable option that remains is merging it into NovaApiPolicy. And the direct use of NovaApiPolicy parameter for extra customizations is no longer possible in fact.

Also I think we cannot rely on direct values for NovaApiPolicies, since it is already being referred in user-faced environments, like RBAC settings. And if a user needs more customizations, the best option would be to merge it with NovaApiPolicies...

I'm not sure what is the difference of rule to role, and what should I place here.
Looking at https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/+/818840 example, I can't get the anwer yet.
or should I use role:reader or role:member ?..
by default this shoudl be admin only but reader is correct.
thanks. the "real" default case would be admins only indeed, please see how this param works alongside NovaShowHostStatus: hidden default

Hi,

Thanks for your feedback. I've clarified the subject line, and now filter hosts before sending out the queries, ensuring we only poll each host once.

The filtering is commented, and I think clear. You could make it more explicit (and slower, since it'll be quadratic rather than almost-linear) with code like
```
        filtered_list = []
        hosts_seen = []
        for t in hosts:
            if t[0] in hosts_seen:
                continue
            hosts_seen.append(t[0])
            filtered_list.append(t)
        filtered_hosts = set(filtered_list)

```
...but I think the concise version is better :-)

Regards,

Matthew

A few things:

- For our immediate need, the wrapper works

- Upstream libvirt has wired up QEMU's 'tb-size' (and also began using '-accel' instead of '-machine accel' by defaults: "[PATCH v2 0/4] Introduce TCG domain features" — https://listman.redhat.com/archives/libvir-list/2021-November/msg00236.html. This will be available from libvirt v.7.10 onwards.

- I've got a WIP patch to wire up config class libvirt's "tb-cache" (i.e. QEMU's "tb-size") libvirt: Introduce config classes for QEMU's "tb-cache"https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/816823.  And then introduce a config option that should be conditionalized on MIN_LIBVIRT version v.7.10

Note that the "tb-size" for `-accel tcg` was introduced in QEMU v.5.0: https://gitlab.com/qemu-project/qemu/-/commit/fe17413247.   (See the text in the "qemu-depreicated.texi" file from the commit.)

So you want to add a version-check for this in the wrapper.

non vdpa - len(pf_nic) == 1 and pf_name == pf_nic[0]
vdpa     - pf_name in pf_nic

Had a detailed look and even discussed with Karthik regarding the condition change. The current change with 'in' should be good enough to handled all 3 modes - legacy, switchdev, vdpa. I will continue to review the changes.

Hello Saravanan,

Sorry for the delay. So this looks like it's an acceptable behavior, at least for the nova engineering team here at Red Hat [a].

Now regarding the condition, I wasn't sure why it wasn't like that before [1], that's why I kept the logic as close as possible what it was for non-vdpa as I didn't want to introduce a bug. If you don't foresee any issue in just "pf_name in pf_nic", we can rewrite this condition to just that.

That would make a lot more sense and make it more readable IMHO as well.

For the record, here's how it looks for vDPA [2]. Feel free to ping me offline if you want access to deployed our vDPA lab and wiggle around.

Thanks,

DVD


[a] https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=2025649

[1]
~~~
 if len(pf_nic) == 1 and pf_name == pf_nic[0]:
~~~

[2]
~~~
pf_path: /sys/devices/pci0000:00/0000:00:02.2/0000:06:01.2/physfn/net
pf_nic: ['enp6s0f1np1_4', 'enp6s0f1np1_2', 'enp6s0f1np1_0', 'enp6s0f1np1_7', 'enp6s0f1np1_5', 'enp6s0f1np1_3', 'enp6s0f1np1_1', 'enp6s0f1np1', 'enp6s0f1np1_6']
pf_name: enp6s0f1np1
~~~

When using pure sriov, pf_nic will always be 1 and pf_name will be the first item of pf_nic.

When using vdpa, pf_nic is going to be a list of the pf and vf as well:

    [root@computevdpa-0 enp6s0f0np0_0]# ls -l device/virtfn2/physfn/net/

    drwxr-xr-x. 5 root root 0 Nov 22 23:40 enp6s0f0np0_7

Should this be a bug in kernel/mlx driver? 

The logic still looks for the pf_name in the list of devices found in 'physfn/net', if found then it is treated as valid device to be added. In cases of legacy and switchdev modes, there will be only one item and that item should have the 'pf_name'. In case of vdpa, there will be multipl items (1 pf + multiple vfs), but we are interested if it has the required pf in the list. To me, this makes the condition simple, 'if pf_name in pf_nic' - WDYT?
Is it possible to merge vf_list and vf_to_pf mapping?
Can this be triggered only for vdpa? and if there are any new devices configured?
If operators are manually creating devices, we are not going to trap the vhost device creation. But if they are create via os-net-config this should fix them.
Is vf representors udev rule applicable for vdpa? does it mean there will be 2 devices - vf representor and then a vhost device (for vdpa)?

> Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1
> 
> I have used the default policy rule 'create_port:port_security_enabled' and created a demo user with a member role and now If I apply this patch it always hides 'Port Security' checkbox for the non-admin user which is Wrong. I have generated default policy rule using the below command in my devstack env:
> ``oslopolicy-policy-generator --namespace neutron --output-file /etc/neutron/policy.yaml`` and updated policy_file path in \etc\neutron\neutron.conf.
> 
> This patch works fine for the policy mentioned in the bug summary.

Can you attach the relevant policy file somewhere?

default policy.yaml for neutron in my env. can be found here https://paste.opendev.org/show/809921/

You can also generate using oslopolicy-policy-generator command.
hi, I can still see the same issue after applying your patch 'port security' checkbox always hide for the non-admin user with the default policy rule.

It says:
"create_port:port_security_enabled": "rule:context_is_advsvc or rule:network_owner or role:admin and system_scope:all or role:admin and project_id:%(project_id)s"

If I read this right, you should have the right as an admin if you have the system scope (which we don't support) or it's your own project?

Did this change recently? It doesn't seem right.
I think I know what's wrong. I need to pass the network id to the policy check, so it can make sure the user is the owner.

You can find the same in neutron code [1]

[1] https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/conf/policies/port.py#L162
It looks like we are always passing the domain name to token creation (the comments say this is necessary for multi-domain support), and this makes oslo.policy think this is a domain-scoped token?

I'm getting this now too, so this is definitely a problem. Looking in the logs, I also get this:

oslo_policy/policy.py:1064: UserWarning: Policy update_port:port_security_enabled failed scope check. The token used to make the request was domain scoped but the policy requires ['system', 'project'] scope. This behavior may change in the future where using the intended scope is required.

Why is this a system scope policy?

> oslo_policy/policy.py:1064: UserWarning: Policy update_port:port_security_enabled failed scope check. The token used to make the request was domain scoped but the policy requires ['system', 'project'] scope. This behavior may change in the future where using the intended scope is required.
> 
> Why is this a system scope policy?

At least a domain scoped token is not correct as there is no resource scoped to a specific domain in neutron.

Regarding the system-scoped, the reason that a system-scoped token is included in the list of the expected token is because neutron allows system-level admin to specify the field on behalf of a project. Note that there were many discussions on how to manipulate a project-level resource with a superuser priviledge (so far and in the last PTG) and it is just what neutron does from the initial era.
I'm now passing the network_id and port_id to the policy check function, so that the ownership checks should work.

It would be nice if someone else could also test your patch then I will do my vote.
Maybe I am missing something.

I think I figured it out, and it seems to work in my tests now.

The trick is to also specify "network:tenant_id" in the target.

The warning about wrong scope is because we pass domain_id always. It's a separate issue.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: Given that rootwrap (and its cousin privsep) is security sensitive, what are the use cases for adding this new configuration capability? Will it introduce a risk for cloud admins that might inadvertently misconfigure something? In my admittedly experience, I thought the rootwrap.conf supplied by most distros is sufficient.
I forgot to remove WIP after I checked current usage of oslo.rootwrap, but I think this one is ready now.

If deployments do need to tune cinder's rootwrap.conf then I'm OK with this patch. As a side note, while I agree that consistency is good, I personally would hold off globally adding this this feature to all puppet modules unless there's an actual need, but that's my personal bias.

As for this patch being WIP, it will be a while before cinder can fully deprecate its reliance on rootwrap, so +2 from me. I'll hold the +w until you're ready to proceed.

oslo.rootwrap supports some logging parameters and tunable parameters which might require customization in some deployments. This file is already supported by puppet-designate and I'm implementing this to have consistent capability in all modules.

One concern with this (and the reason I put WIP) is that there is a desire to replace oslo.rootwrap by oslo.privsep[1] . However considering the fact that many components are still using oslo.rootwrap, this capability would be still useful, IMO.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/oslo.privsep/latest/user/index.html#converting-from-rootwrap-to-privsep

self.os_system_admin.auth_provider.credentials.\
            project_domain_name= None

yea passing the Token till self.os_system_admin is quite complex implementation in Tempest. 

We can pass the scope thing from test.py all the way down to auth_provider which is being used to instantiate the service clients for particular os_*.

we can inject the scope like below:

1. test.py->get_client_manager()[1]create the manager class which takes credential and scope for auth_provider. 

2. created credential from configured credential_provider [2] has the credential.system info in it. Which is from this patch implementation. 

3. Now when test.py create the Manager class [3], it pass only created credential not scope. 

4. By default scope in Manager class is 'project' [4] which gets passed to base class[5]

5. Then base class ServiceClients pass that scope to auth_provider[6] self.auth_provider 

6. and further self.auth_provider is passed to ClientsFactory and then used to instantiate the service_clients[7]> where auth_request and token with scope is created while any APi call via service_clients.

So if in step 3, if credentials_type=system then, we pass scope=system to Manager class which will set the system scope to auth_provider.  That way os_system.* will be system scoped. And then we donot need to set the scope to system here. 

[1] https://github.com/openstack/tempest/blob/75048e4c86e777a6db87de47dd3e20ed9f57fa9e/tempest/test.py#L640

[2] https://github.com/openstack/tempest/blob/75048e4c86e777a6db87de47dd3e20ed9f57fa9e/tempest/test.py#L674

/lib/services/clients.py#L260

[6] https://github.com/openstack/tempest/blob/9594233ffd93066677aa601c594d55f3a4f188d8/tempest/lib/services/clients.py#L351


[7] https://github.com/openstack/tempest/blob/9594233ffd93066677aa601c594d55f3a4f188d8/tempest/lib/services/clients.py#L211

files/udev/95-charm-ceph-osd.rules.message: This seems very general - is there no specific way of detecting a Ceph created luks volume?

> is there no specific way of detecting a Ceph created luks volume?

I think, no. At the time, I do agree that this is generic and could unintentionally change ownership of someone else's devices.

The internal dm device created doesn't have any way to identify that it was created by ceph-volum (it's created when --dmcrypt is passed to ceph-volume. I don't see a way to supply a name, either (a known prefix like we do for the osd data, for example).

An alternative I can think of is to look at /var/lib/ceph/osd/ceph-*/block and get the actual device and then change permission of that device. This can be done using a script that gets run by a udev rule. I'll do this change and then we can see if it's viable.

files/udev/ceph-osd-perms.sh.message:
This approach feels likely to be racey and only covers the block device personality - db and wal are not covered.

Its important that the permissions are set on the block devices before ceph tries to use them - checking for the links in the OSD directory feels to late.

hooks/neutron_contexts.py.message: Shouldn't be an argument - this suggests that there may be a different config key in the charm config used for the same purpose. Better to either use it directly or define a constant like DNS_CONFIG_KEY. I personally like the former better for this case.

In this case the relation_ids part is correct, but the relation_get part with local_unit() is not because you simply take the ingress_address address value of a local neutron-gateway unit and use it as a dns server endpoint.

Instead you need to iterate like this:

dns_servers_conf = config('dns-servers')
dns_servers = set(dns_servers_conf.split(',')) if dns_servers_conf else set([])

for relid in relation_ids('neutron-recursive-dns'):
    for remote_unit in related_units(relid):
       # charmhelpers.core.hookenv.ingress_address
       dns_servers.add(relation_get(attribute='ingress-address', unit=remote_unit, rid=relid))

return ', '.join(dns_servers)

hooks/multisite.py.message: Just a nit, but wouldn't it be more robust to check for `!= 0` rather than exactly for 2 ? I haven't looked at the radosgw code itself to see if the 2 is hardcoded, but it can be a bit frail if for any reason the return code is changed.

Actually, ceph commands return standard errno's and e.returncode == 2 is equivalent to errno.ENOENT, which is no such file or directory. The check for e.returncode == errno.ENOENT may be enough without checking for the `No such file` in e.stderr (though it doesn't hurt).

Luciano: the reason for having a specific check for return code is that at this point in time I do not know what other error conditions that program might get into, and I only want to handle this specific error condition in this way. Any other error conditions should cause an exception to be raised so that we can diagnose and add code to handle it appropriately if it happens.

Billy: I did go to look through the code for how error codes was used, but gave up after the N-th layer of calls. If my brain was functioning normally I should have recognized the standard errno values being used though ;)
